pages.name: Affidavit – Personal Service
pages.description:
An `affidavit of personal service` is used to prove service of document(s) to the court. It is a written document that contains facts about the personal service and the person who completed the personal service must swear under oath (usually on a Bible or other religious book) or affirm (non-religious promise) the facts to be true. After the affidavit of personal service is sworn or affirmed by the person who completed the personal service, it is evidence of the facts and events it sets out, just as if the person took the stand in a courtroom to provide those facts.
An affidavit:
  • must be sworn by the person who completed the personal service on the other party
  • must be in the first person (from the writer’s point of view, using “I”)
  • must include facts (who you served, date and time of service, place of service and documents served)
  • must identify the source of your information if certain facts are not within your personal knowledge and
  • must have copies of the documents that were served on the other party referenced and attached to it - these are called exhibits.
If the person writing the affidavit needs help with English, click on the Language Resources link on the bottom toolbar for more information about interpreters and other resources to help with preparing court forms.

elements.name: FAQLegalAdvice
elements.title: How do I swear or affirm an affidavit?
elements.body:
To swear or affirm an affidavit, the person who served the documents must meet with a commissioner for taking oaths. The commissioner will check their photo ID to make sure they are who you say you are, ask the person if they understand the contents of the affidavit, then ask them to swear or affirm that the contents are true. The commissioner will then watch them sign the document before signing it themselves.

If the person does not speak or read English, they can bring an interpreter with them when they meet with the commissioner. For information about interpreters and language help, click on the Language Resources link on the bottom toolbar.

Lawyers, notary publics and many court registry staff are commissioners for taking oaths. The person who served the documents can go to any Provincial Court Registry or Service BC location to swear or affirm the affidavit. If they have the document sworn or affirmed at a different court registry, you will still need to file it at the court registry where the existing case is filed.

elements.name: affidavitHeading
elements.html: Do not sign the affidavit until you are with a commissioner for taking affidavits and they tell you to sign it. Make sure that you bring any documents you are attaching to your affidavit as exhibits with you. The commissioner will also need to date and sign the exhibits.

elements.name: FAQLegalAdvice
elements.title: What document(s) are required to be personally served?
elements.body:
There are specific documents that require personal service by an adult who is not a party or the person to be served.
  • an application about a family law matter
  • summons or subpoena
  • application about a protection order
  • a protection order, if the person against whom the protection order application is made was not present in court
  • a request for court enforcement under the Family Maintenance Enforcement Act
  • any document that the court has determined requires personal service
  • any application to be served on a party who has not provided an address of service
Service is the act of giving or leaving documents with the required person. Personal service requires that an adult (at least 19 years old) who is not a party hand-deliver the documents to the party to be served.
A document is deemed to have been personally served on a person,
  • If the document (s) is served at or before 4 p.m. on a day that is not a Saturday or holiday, the document is deemed to be served on the day of service, or
  • If the document(s) is served on a Saturday or holiday or after 4 p.m. on any other day, the document is deemed to be served on the next day that is not a Saturday or holiday.

elements.name: FAQLegalAdvice
elements.title: How do I reference and attach an exhibit?
elements.body:
Exhibits are documents that you attach to the affidavit of personal service, usually to support a fact you talk about in the affidavit of personal service. For example, if you say that you served an application about a family matter, you will need to attach a filed copy to show the document that you served.
When you attach an exhibit, you must introduce it in your affidavit. To introduce it, you must indicate what the document is, reference the document, and say that you are attaching it as an exhibit.
Each exhibit is identified with a letter, Exhibit “A”, “B”, “C” and so on. For example:
Exhibit A – Application About a Family Law Matter filed Jan 24, 2022. The application is attached to this affidavit as Exhibit A.
